item.title: Nuclear Reactions
item.description: Thomas Kuhn scintific revolution Wilhelm Herschel color temps Bunsen and Kirchoff discovery of colour Dynamics of nuclear reactions The basic scheme for a nuclear reaction is a_{\text{projectile}}+A_{\text{target}}\to B_{\text{recoil}}+b_{ejectile} The expected condition is a\neq b and A\neq B.

item.title: homogenous equation
item.description: Solving First-Order Homogeneous ODEs For ODEs of the form dydx=f(yx)\frac{dy}{dx} = f\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)dxdy​=f(xy​), use the substitution v=yxv = \frac{y}{x}v=xy​, where y=vxy = vxy=vx and dydx=v+xdvdx\frac{dy}{dx} = v + x\frac{dv}{dx}dxdy​=v+xdxdv​.

item.title: Bounds of a function
item.description: refer Bounds of a singleton set and Maxima vs Supremum Transclude of Riemann-Integration-2024-12-10-12.07.19.excalidraw Mapping of a function, A function f is said to be bounded if there exists m,M\in \mathbb{R} such that m \leq f(x) \leq M \forall x in the domain.

item.title: Stokes theorem
item.description: \oint\vec{F}\cdot d\vec{r}=\iint_{S}\nabla \times \vec{F} \cdot\hat{n} \quad dS If S is a surface bounded by a simple closed curve C and \vec{F} is a vector function whoms components have continuous first order derivatives.

item.title: Bragg's Law
item.description: Let us consider a crystal made up of equidistant parallel planes of atoms with the inter- planer spacing dhkl.

item.title: K space
item.description: A space where we take wavelength to be ‘unit’.

item.title: Occupation number of Boson
item.description: Mean contribution of a boson to the number density of a boson system Density of states - no of bosons per unit volume.

item.title: X- rays
item.description: Highly energetic eelctrons e^- falling on metal target produce xrays.

item.title: coolidge tube
item.description: The intensity of Xray dpends on filament of current, the quality of Xray is dependent on Voltage across the filament The photons are released as a form of Bremsstrahlung radiation when an electron passing by a nucleus bends - changing it’s velocity.

item.title: Scintillation detector
item.description: 4 marks A typical photomultiplier has multiplication factor of 10^6 electrons, i.e each electron creates million electrons There are n stages in a dynode, of multiplication factor of m.
